comment: For the code at 40:20, I feel that the answer for num_guesses will always be 1 short of the actual answer unless we initialize num_guesses at 1 and not zero.

An "all possible inputs" approach for cheer loop (Eric taught me 😐):  an_letters = "aefhilmnorsxAEFHILMNORSX" word = input("I will cheer for you!. Enter a word: 
") times = int(input("Enthusiasm level (1 - 10):
")) if times > 10:     while times > 10:         times = int(input("Please ensure an enthusiasm level between 1-10
"))  for char in word:     if char == ' ':         continue     if char in an_letters:         print("Give me an " + char + "! " + char)     else:         print("Give me a " + char + "! " + char) print("What does that spell?") print((word + "!!!
")*times)

Here's what I have for bisection search that accounts for negative numbers and abs (numbers) < 1: cube = -0.027 epsilon = 0.0001 num_guesses = 0 if cube >= 1:     low = 0     high = cube elif cube >= 0 and cube < 1:     low = cube     high = 1 elif cube < 0 and cube > -1:     low = -1     high = cube else:     low = cube     high = 0  if abs(cube) == 1:     guess = cube else:     guess = (high + low) / 2.0 while abs(guess**3 - cube) >= epsilon:     if guess**3 < cube:         low = guess     else:         high = guess     guess = (high + low) / 2.0     num_guesses += 1 print('num_guess is', num_guesses) print(guess, 'is close to cube root of', cube)

Nice tutorial and lesson. Just a small note, IMHO, on ~35:00 Anna made a small "mistake" when added "and guess<= cube" to the test condition. Epsilon is an error range, so the correct answer (in general) is << Cube-epsilon<=guess**3<=Cube+epsilon >>. Therefore the test condition in the example should be "and guess<= cube+epsilon" or test should be rewritten according like within <<...>>

Guess & Check:   cube = -27    # only guess the first natural number for which guess**3 >= cube for guess in range(abs(cube)+1):     if guess**3 >= abs(cube):         break    # return perfect cube, if exists if guess**3 == abs(cube):     if cube < 0:         print("Cube root of  " + str(cube) + " is " + str(-guess))      else:         print("Cube root of  " + str(cube) + " is " + str(guess))    # if there exists no perfect cube else:     print(str(cube) + " is not a perfect cube")

@26:01 Note that the scope of the index variable 'guess' is not limited to the for loop indentation as in other languages. It can be, and is in this case, referenced in the subsequent code.  This can get you into trouble.   https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2015/the-scope-of-index-variables-in-pythons-for-loops/

cube = float(input("Enter a no whose cube root is to be calculated: ")) epsilon = 0.01 num_guesses = 0 if cube > 1:     low = 0     high = cube     guess = (low + high)/2.0     while abs(guess**3 - cube) >= epsilon:         if guess**3 < cube:             low = guess         else:             high = guess         guess = (low + high)/2.0         num_guesses += 1 elif 0 < cube < 1:     low = cube     high = 1     guess = (low + high)/2.0     while abs(guess**3 - cube) >= epsilon:         if guess**3 < cube:             low = guess         else:             high = guess         guess = (low + high)/2.0         num_guesses += 1 elif -1 < cube < 0:     low = cube     high = 1     guess = (abs(low) + high)/2.0     while abs(guess**3 - abs(cube)) >= epsilon:         if guess**3 < abs(cube):             low = guess         else:             high = guess         guess = (low + high)/2.0         num_guesses += 1 else:     low = cube     high = 0     guess = (abs(low) + high)/2.0     while abs(guess**3 - abs(cube)) >= epsilon:         if guess**3 < abs(cube):             low = guess         else:             high = guess         guess = (low + high)/2.0         num_guesses += 1  print('num_guesses = ', num_guesses) if cube < 0 :     guess = -guess print(guess, "is close to the cube root of", cube)  I guess this covers all possible cases?

What I get from the approximation algorithm is that it will only give you an answer if the difference between guess**3 and cube is equal to epsilon, if it manages to jump above epsilon, guess will increase in value until it is <= cube, and thus the message "failed to obtain a value" will appear. How can we make it so that if the difference does jump above epsilon that the value will get will be the value of guess at time - 1 of that moment.

cube = 10000 epsilon = 0.1 guess = 0.0 increment = 0.01 num_guesses= 0 while abs(guess**3 -cube) >= epsilon: # and guess <= cube : 	c=guess                                                                                                 # to have  previous guess stored (new inserted line) 	guess += increment 	num_guesses+= 1 	if abs(guess**3 -cube) >= epsilon and guess**3 > cube:                                                        # new inserted line 		print("sorry the the epsilon jumped up and the cube is not found the last guess was",c)         # new inserted line 		break                                                                                                                                                 # new inserted line print('num_guesses=', num_guesses) if abs(guess**3 -cube) >= epsilon: 	print('Failed on cube root of', cube) else: 	print(guess, 'is close to the cube root of', cube)
Note that f-strings are only available from python 3.6 onward.

Yes, that is right. Since the second parameter of the range function, the end point, is taken as a non-inclusive endpoint, if you want the loop to go over that number as well you need to add one. So to make it include 8 rather than stop after 7, just as you said.

Code at 35:33 does not work for negative cubes. Here some changes in order to let it work also for negative numbers. Hope it will be useful :).  _________________________________________________________________________________ cube = 27 epsilon = 0.01 guess = 0.0 increment = 0.0001 num_guesses = 0  while abs(guess**3 - cube) >= epsilon and abs(guess**3) <= abs(cube):     # the increment must be negative if cube < 0 and intitial guess = 0, otherwise (guess**3 - cube) will always increase as guess increases     guess += cube/abs(cube)*increment      num_guesses+=1 print('num_guesses =', num_guesses) if abs(guess**3 - cube) >= epsilon:     print('Failed on cube root of', cube) else:     print(guess, 'is close to the cube root of', cube)

it's because for each value of guess in ur range it is going to execute either if or else statement definitely .u can correct the code using while statement that continues checking for cuberoot untill guess is less than equal to cube(or cube\4...just to optimize),only when guess reaches cube and u didnt get cuberoot its going to print cuberoot dsnt exist.....hope u get it :)

let's assume you want the cube root of 27. Just remove the else statement. When python iterates it starts from 0 and it checks the condition if  0^3 not equal to 27 it will print "cube root doesn't exist". Similarly, it will do this for all numbers except 3. So if you will remove the else statement it will show result only if it is a perfect square.  And if you want to get "Cube root doesn't exist" as the output use the following code: cube = int(input('type the no....')) for guess in range(cube+1):     if guess**3 == cube:         print("Cube root of", cube, "is", guess)         break     elif guess**3> cube:         print("Cube root doesn't exist")         break  #You can dm me if you want to understand the reasoning behind the code.
@androtech7885  why are we writing range(cube+1) instead of *range(cube)*?

@mussabsaleem7625  If we'll think mathematically, keeping just range cube not cube+1 may give error in some cases. Since ranges are indexed from zero, so taking x in range doesn't mean the number x is included it means, x-1 numbers are included. (Eg. Range(5) includes 0, 1,2,3,4). Ao suppose the we need to find cube root of 1, which is 1 of course, but if the code had been range(cube) which is one, it wouldn't have included 1 in rhe range and would have given us a wrong answer. Though in most cases cuberoot is smaller than the number itself, but a code is said to effective if it includes all extreme cases also.

if abs(cube) < 1.0:         high = 1.0  This worked for me. Logic is that if 1 is less than 0 we just need to change the higher bound and a good number to change it to is 1 because the answer won't be greater than one anyway.
@vmalonbc  if cube < 1:     high = 1     low = guess And even with that you may have an infinite loop because doing comparison for float numbers is tricky, see the style guide pdf

The index notation uses colons, not commas, so it would be word[1:3]. But other than that, yes, you could do that, and then you would loop over only the characters that are in that substring. So if the original string word is "ROBOTS", the substring word[1:3] would be "OB".

Assignment 2.3 Bisectional Search:  salary = []   def optimal_savings_rate():     current_savings = 0.00     semi_annual_salary_raise = 7.00     down_payment = 250000.00     epsilon = 100     high = 1.00     low = 0.00     count = 0     portion_saved = (high + low) / 2     annual_salary = float(input("What is your annual salary?"))     salary.append(annual_salary)     """Lets's check for sufficiency of the person's annual salary."""     """Take portion saved as %100. Would it be enough to save for down payment?"""     """With a for loop we save each semi years salary to salary list."""     """Then check if sum of them is enough to pay down payment."""     for i in range(6):         annual_salary += (annual_salary * semi_annual_salary_raise * 0.01)         salary.append(annual_salary)     if (salary[1] + salary[2] + salary[3]+ salary[4] + salary[5] + salary[6]) / 2 < down_payment:             print("Not enough income to have a saving equivalent to down payment in three years")             return "Sorry."     """After being sure about the sufficiency of the annual salary, we can begin to make a research bisectionally."""     while abs(current_savings - down_payment) > epsilon:         current_savings = 0         annual_salary = salary[0]         for i in range(0, 36):             """Raise the salary each six month. Don't take first month."""             if i % 6 == 0 and i != 0:                 annual_salary += (annual_salary * semi_annual_salary_raise * 0.01)             monthly_salary = annual_salary / 12             monthly_savings_income = current_savings * 0.04 / 12             monthly_savings = (monthly_salary * portion_saved) + monthly_savings_income             current_savings += monthly_savings         if current_savings < down_payment:             low = portion_saved         if current_savings > down_payment:             high = portion_saved         portion_saved = (high + low) / 2         count += 1     print("The proper saving portion would be really close to {}.Binary "           "step count = {}".format(round(portion_saved,4), count))   optimal_savings_rate()

# This might be of help to someone as I had trouble following along due to this misconception # Assign the string "MIT" to variable "i" i = 'MIT'  # Print the elements of variable "i" starting from index 0 and ending at index 3 but not including index 3 - "[0:3]" print(i[0:3])  # When working with an index remember that it starts at 0 "[0:]" # when specifying where you would like to end the index "[:3]" it's up to the index value 3 but not including it # So in this example - "M" is located at index 0 #                                      "I" is located at index 1  #                                     "T" is located at index 2 # >>> MIT  # If we were to print the elements of variable "i" at index "[0:2]" it would be print(i[0:2])  # >>> MI #       "M" is located at index 0 #       "I" is located at index 1  #       "T" is located at index 2 # Rember it's up to the index value 2 but not including it

From my understanding conceptually, it is simply a "threshold" value you use to compare things with. When comparing two values(mainly irrational ones I would assume), if your EPSILON it is within a certain size that you say is" good enough" then you use it. Basically a way of saying the value returned is "good enough" although  not truly accurate.  PI = 3.14159 is "good enough" albeit not correct for the value of half the circumference of a unit circle.  You can use an EPSILON value to change what your threshold is of what you consider "good enough"  Hope someone else reads this and can elaborate or correct
It also is used in Calc : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/(ε,_δ)-definition_of_limit and actually here's a pdf with notation explanations: http://www.unm.edu/~ckbutler/ps541/MathNotation.pdf

See code below.   # For cube < 0  cube = -27 epsilon = 0.01 numOfGuess = 1 high = cube low = 0 guess = (high + low)/2.0 while abs(abs(guess**3) - abs(cube)) >= epsilon:     if abs(guess**3) > abs(cube):         high = guess     else:         low = guess     guess = (high + low)/2     numOfGuess += 1     print("high is "+str(high))     print("low is "+str(low)) print("Number of Guess is "+str(numOfGuess)) print(guess)

@MrFaiqueShakil  Check out Miles' code, they only thing they have changed is the bounds. For 0 < cube < 1, low = cube and high = 1, because the answer will be between cube and 1, not cube and 0. So all you need to add to the lecture code is:   if 0 < cube < 1:     low = cube     high = 1   And the program searches within different bounds when cube is between 1 and 0.
